description: From Middle English sukelen; probably a back-formation of Middle English sukeling (“a suckling; infant”), formally equivalent to suck +‎ -le (frequentative suffix). See suckling.

examples: […]  the body of this fish [the Mannatee] is commonly 3 yards long and one broad, slow in swimming, wanting fins, in their place ayded with 2 paps which are not only suckles but stilts to creep a shoare upon such time she grazes  […]
The baby was having a suckle at its mother's breast.

verbs.description: suckle (third-person singular simple present suckles, present participle suckling, simple past and past participle suckled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give suck to; to nurse at the breast, udder, or dugs.
(intransitive) To nurse; to suck milk from a nursing mother.
examples: But out of the woman’s great brown breast the milk gushed forth for the child, milk as white as snow, and when the child suckled at one breast it flowed like a fountain from the other, and she let it flow.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To nurse from (a breast, nursing mother, etc.).
examples: Buz attempted to suckle his left nipple.
